subsections.title: 2.1 Scope
subsections.content:
The NND project manual applies to all project participants in the NND project, consisting of the companies Axpo Power AG (Axpo), Kernkraftwerk Leibstadt AG (KKL) and
Zwilag Zwischenlager Würenlingen AG (Zwilag) in all phases of the project period. The regulations set out in the project manual are binding for all project participants.

subsections.title: 2.2 Aim and purpose
subsections.content:
This project manual specifies how the NND project is to be managed and controlled. It describes the tasks, responsibilities, processes and regulates basic specifications
and boundary conditions with the aim of fulfilling the project mandate.
The purpose of the project manual is to ensure that:
•
the project structure is clearly defined,
•
the project organization as well as tasks, competencies and responsibilities are clearly regulated
are,
•
Processes for uniform planning, implementation and control of the project are defined,
•
rules for communication are established and adhered to,
•
a uniform documentation of documents and information is carried out
•
there is successful cooperation between the project and line organization.
In this respect, the project manual also serves as a quality assurance instrument.
The NND Project Management Office (PMO) is responsible for updating and maintaining the project manual.

subsections.title: 2.3 Principles & Success Factors
subsections.content:
The following principles apply to the processing of the project. The NND project
•
is based on the principles of certified project management (IPMA),
•
has a clearly defined mandate from the client (Chairman of the Steering Committee),
•
has a project organization and a clear definition of responsibilities,
•
has an appropriate work breakdown structure (WBS). The work packages all have a
work package description,
•
has a schedule based on the WBS in an appropriate level of detail, which
is continuously updated,
•
has a current budget plan, divided into the work packages and is presented in a
binding cost structure plan documented and updated,
•
carries out a continuous risk assessment at work package level
Critical success factors:
•
The project bodies receive the resources necessary to carry out their functions and to fulfil their
tasks necessary action competence
•
The safe and economical operation of the plants, taking into account the technical, organizational and human factors (HOF), is NND's highest priority.
•
It is therefore always important to ensure that set deadlines are met - and if not, to escalate as early as possible in order to avoid damage or additional costs
in the project.
•
Across the company, management and those involved contribute to and support the goals and approach through the Project Chair (PV) and the Steering
Committee (SteCo).
•
Qualified resources are available in each phase.

prerequisites: Understanding of basic project management principles (e.g., IPMA or similar frameworks).
Familiarity with work breakdown structures (WBS) and risk assessment in projects.
learningGoals: Understand the principles and guidelines outlined in the NND project manual.
Learn how to define project structures, responsibilities, and processes for effective management.
Gain insights into quality assurance and risk assessment methods in project management.

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Welcome! Today, we’re going to explore the principles of the NND project manual. By the end, you'll understand its purpose, structure, and key success factors. Ready to dive in?

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: Yes, sounds interesting! What exactly is the NND project manual, and who uses it?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Great question! The NND project manual is a document that guides all participants in the NND project. These participants are from Axpo Power AG, Kernkraftwerk Leibstadt AG, and Zwilag Zwischenlager Würenlingen AG. It’s applicable in every phase of the project.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: I see. What does this manual aim to achieve?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Its main purpose is to ensure the project operates smoothly and effectively. It defines the project structure, tasks, responsibilities, processes, communication rules, and documentation standards. Think of it as a blueprint for quality assurance during the entire project.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: That makes sense. Can you give an example of how it helps in practice?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Sure! Imagine you're managing a construction project. If everyone had different ways of documenting progress, it could cause confusion. The NND project manual provides uniform processes for planning, control, and communication, ensuring everyone is on the same page. For instance, it mandates a clear schedule and budget plan based on a detailed Work Breakdown Structure (WBS).

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: Okay, but who ensures that the manual stays updated and relevant throughout the project?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Good point! The NND Project Management Office (PMO) is responsible for maintaining and updating the manual. They ensure it remains aligned with the ongoing needs of the project.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: Got it. What principles guide the NND project management process?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: The NND project follows key principles based on certified project management standards, like IPMA. It has a clear mandate from the client, a well-defined project organization, a detailed WBS with descriptions for each work package, an updated schedule, and a budget plan. It also includes continuous risk assessments for proactive problem-solving.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: Interesting! What are the critical success factors for the project?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Critical success factors include proper resource allocation, adherence to deadlines, and ensuring safe and economical operations. For example, if a deadline might be missed, the issue must be escalated early to minimize costs and risks. Additionally, management and project participants must actively support the goals and processes.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: It sounds like a lot of coordination is required. Are qualified resources ensured at every stage?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Absolutely. Qualified resources are made available in every phase to guarantee smooth execution. This ensures that all technical, organizational, and human factors are accounted for effectively.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: Thanks for explaining! So, to summarize, the manual provides structure, processes, and rules for effective project management, and it’s backed by strong principles and success factors, right?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Exactly! The NND project manual ensures clarity, consistency, and quality through detailed processes and principles. It’s a vital tool for managing complex projects effectively and achieving desired outcomes.

subsections.title: 3.1 Project assignment
subsections.content:
The nuclear plants - Leibstadt Nuclear Power Plant (KKL), Beznau Nuclear Power Plant (KKB) and the Zwilag
Zwischenlager Würenlingen AG - have largely adapted their business IT to the previous internal IT
Axpo's service provider, Avectris (now Aveniq), outsourced. With the entry into force of ENSI Directive G-22
In 2020, new requirements must be implemented for all three plants.
These requirements are:
1. Establishment of own data centers on the premises of the three plants to ensure
island operation capability
2. Ensuring the authority of the power plant management through appropriate processes and
separate domains In addition, the Axpo Group is relying on a new enterprise architecture, which is heavily based on cloud
Computing. This is not feasible for the Nuclear Energy Division and the KKL and Zwilag plants, among other things for the regulatory reasons mentioned above.
Last but not least, the service quality and performance of the current IT service provider Aveniq does not meet the requirements of the plants.
The NND project has the task of successfully implementing the IT requirements of the Nuclear Energy Division and those of the KKL and Zwilag plants through the
corresponding project goals, which not least requires the insourcing of the entire business IT.

subsections.title: 3.3 Project objectives
subsections.content:
ID main goals
Z1 Construction of a completely new IT infrastructure to ensure island operation capability.
Z2 Development of an IT architecture to meet the increased requirements for IT security of critical infrastructures and the Goods Control Ordinance.
Z3 Establishment of a new IT organizational unit (KI) in the Nuclear Division with local teams in the nuclear facilities, which will manage the operation and the associated
Services (QA, reporting, ticketing, etc.) of business IT can be provided independently.
Z4 Establishment of an adapted process organization (from the IT management system to the individual processes) including the regulation of cooperation with the
individual Demand IT of the nuclear facilities, which trigger the requirements and orders to the AI organization.
The construction of a completely new infrastructure and the increase in IT security levels are the project goals that determine the budget. The requirements and the
resulting project goals were coordinated with Axpo IT in order to take synergies into account.

subsections.title: 3.4 Project scope (In-Scope/Out-of-Scope)
subsections.content:
The project scope of services and delivery describes the content of the project NND. In addition to the description of the deliveries and services of the project, the non-
services (out-of-scope) must be defined.
The specifications and requirements documents are used to describe the specific delivery items or services that are to be provided by suppliers.
The project scope is determined together with the key stakeholders in the preliminary phase or in the preliminary project and can be adjusted until the end of the detailed
engineering phase. In the following phases, it can only be changed through change requests.
Out-of-Scope:
demarcation Description
•
Operational Technology (OT):
The safety-relevant OT systems in nuclear facilities (according to ENSI G01) are not in the scope of NND. These systems are already operated in separate physical
networks with their own processes and largely dedicated personnel and were not affected by the Aveniq/Avectris outsourcing.
•
Security Operation Centers (SOC):
The use of a SOC makes sense and is intended for the future. This is currently outside the scope of NND and will be addressed again when defining future operational
services, e.g. purchasing externally as a service, as implemented in KKG.
•
Demand IT staff
Any hiring and budgeting of in-house and external personnel by Demand IT is not within the scope of NND.
•
Personnel for specialist applications BFS and SAP
The in-house staff responsible for the application operation of the specialist applications "Operational Management Systems" (BFS) and "SAP" remain in the nuclear plant
organization (KKL 5 FTE and KKB 3 FTE). This staff is not budgeted within NND, but is to be viewed in the overall context as part of the IT organization. In future, the
platform operation of the servers will be carried out by staff from the new KI organizational unit. The basic operation of SAP will be ensured by external staff.

subsections.title: 3.5 Project categorization
subsections.content:
Due to its complexity and scope, the NND project was categorised as a class A project (FDB/0092, WDK006) (FDB/0092, WDK006) according to the KKL project portfolio
manual (FDB/0092), WDK006 and the administrative directive on project management of Zwilag (ZWI 2700/D0001). Accordingly, high demands must be placed on the
project management methodology and the project management system.

prerequisites: Basic understanding of IT infrastructure and architecture principles.
Familiarity with regulatory compliance in critical infrastructures (e.g., ENSI Guideline G22).
Knowledge of project management methodologies for large-scale IT projects.
learningGoals: Understand the IT requirements for nuclear facilities, including island operation and IT security.
Learn about the challenges and solutions for insourcing business IT in regulated environments.
Gain insights into the goals and scope of the NND project for nuclear facilities.
Identify the in-scope and out-of-scope elements of IT infrastructure projects.

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Welcome! Today, we’ll discuss the NND project and its importance in redefining business IT for nuclear facilities. Our goal is to understand the key requirements, objectives, and scope of this project.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: Sounds interesting! Why is this project so critical for nuclear facilities?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Great question! The NND project is crucial because it addresses the IT-specific regulatory requirements imposed by ENSI Guideline G22. For example, nuclear plants like Leibstadt, Beznau, and Zwilag need to establish their own data centers to ensure island operation capability. This means that their IT systems can function independently, even during emergencies.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: What do you mean by ‘island operation capability’? Could you clarify with an example?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Sure! Imagine a scenario where the external power grid fails due to a cyberattack or natural disaster. With island operation capability, the nuclear facility’s IT systems can continue running autonomously without relying on external resources. This ensures operational continuity and safety.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: That makes sense. What other requirements does the NND project need to fulfill?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: The project has several critical requirements. For instance, IT security must ensure availability, integrity, confidentiality, and non-repudiation of information. Additionally, the management of each nuclear site must have explicit authority over IT security. There’s also a strict restriction on exporting nuclear technology data abroad, as per the Goods Control Ordinance.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: So, the NND project not only focuses on security but also on local control and regulatory compliance?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Exactly! And beyond that, the project aims to reduce costs by leveraging synergies among the nuclear facilities. For example, creating a unified IT architecture that meets all these requirements can save resources while ensuring security.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: What about the main goals of the project? Can you summarize them for me?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Of course! The main goals include building a completely new IT infrastructure to enable island operation capability, developing a secure IT architecture, establishing a new IT organizational unit within the Nuclear Division, and creating tailored IT processes. These goals ensure the independence and compliance of business IT with regulatory standards.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: But what happens if something is out of the project’s scope? How is that managed?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Good point! Certain areas, like Operational Technology (OT) systems and Security Operation Centers (SOC), are not part of the NND project because they are already managed separately. Similarly, staffing for specialized applications like SAP isn’t included but is considered in the overall IT organization.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: That’s clear. It seems like the project management must be quite complex given the scope and requirements.

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Absolutely. The NND project is categorized as a Class A project, which means it requires meticulous project management and adherence to strict methodologies. This ensures every phase, from preliminary engineering to delivery, is handled efficiently.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: What’s the biggest challenge in implementing this project?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: The biggest challenge is meeting all the regulatory requirements, particularly those outlined in ENSI Guideline G22, while ensuring seamless insourcing of business IT. At the same time, the project must manage costs and align with Axpo Group’s enterprise architecture.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: This seems like a massive undertaking. Can you summarize the key takeaways for me?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Certainly! The NND project aims to transform the business IT of nuclear facilities to meet regulatory and operational requirements. Key focuses include IT security, island operation capability, local control, and cost efficiencies. Out-of-scope items, like Operational Technology and SOC, are managed separately. Finally, the project’s success depends on its robust management and alignment with Axpo’s broader IT strategy.

subsections.title: 4.2 Steering Committee (SteCo)
subsections.content:
The main task of the SteCo is to ensure the success of the project strategically and across all companies, in terms of overarching decision-making and as the highest
escalation authority. It meets regularly (normally once a quarter) or depending on events and takes on the role of the client. The project manager prepares the SteCo
meetings and takes part in the SteCo.
tasks/responsibilities
• Assumption of overall project responsibility
• Defining strategic goals
• Clarifying strategic questions
• Direction in the event of conflicting goals
• Evaluation of project results via reporting
• Escalation point in case of conflicts (especially between project and line)
• Approval or rejection of project applications
• Appointment or replacement of the project manager
• Approval of procurements from the specified budget level according to financial competencies
(Chapter 17).

subsections.title: 4.3 Project Chair (PV)
subsections.content:
The project chair represents the interests of the client (chair of the steering committee) in the project. His main task is to ensure the operational success of the project.
The project chair covers the following functions, among others:
• Head of Project Chair
• Department head (responsible for IT)
• Strategic Purchasing (Axpo)
• Corporate Controlling (Axpo)
• Information Security Office (Axpo)
The project chair usually meets every two to three months or as events arise. The project manager prepares and attends the PV meetings.
tasks / responsibilities
• Ensuring project success.
• Evaluation of project results.
• Agreeing and evaluating project management objectives.
• Clarifying the project framework.
• Escalation point in conflicts
• Project communication and project marketing in coordination with the project manager
• Project risk owner
• Request and approval of changes:
o the project assignment
o the project manual
o the project objectives
o the project organization
o project planning
o the final project report
o financial release via PL and under SteCo.

prerequisites: Basic understanding of project management principles
Familiarity with organizational structures and roles
Knowledge of escalation processes in corporate environments
learningGoals: Understand the roles and responsibilities of the Steering Committee (SteCo) in project management
Identify the key functions and tasks of the project chair
Learn how decisions and escalations are handled within the project structure

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Today, we’ll explore project organization and committee structure. Specifically, we'll discuss the roles of the SteCo and the project chair. By the end, you’ll understand how they ensure a project's strategic and operational success.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: That sounds interesting! What exactly is the SteCo, and what does it do?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: The SteCo, or steering committee, is like the board of directors for a project. It ensures the project’s strategic success across all companies involved. Think of it as the highest authority, making overarching decisions and resolving escalated issues. For example, if two departments disagree on project goals, the SteCo steps in to resolve the conflict.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: Got it. So, how often does the SteCo meet, and who prepares for these meetings?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: The SteCo typically meets quarterly, although meetings can be scheduled based on significant events. The project manager is responsible for preparing these meetings and also participates in them.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: What are the specific responsibilities of the SteCo?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: The SteCo has a range of responsibilities, including defining strategic goals, clarifying high-level questions, evaluating project results through reports, and acting as an escalation point in conflicts—especially between the project and line functions. For instance, if procurement delays are impacting the timeline, the SteCo might intervene to resolve the issue.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: Does the SteCo have the authority to make personnel or budget decisions?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Yes, the SteCo can approve or reject project applications, appoint or replace the project manager, and approve procurements above certain budget thresholds, following financial competencies outlined in Chapter 17. Essentially, they oversee major strategic decisions.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: Interesting! Now, what about the project chair? How is their role different from the SteCo?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Great question! While the SteCo focuses on strategic oversight, the project chair ensures the operational success of the project. Think of them as the captain steering the ship, representing the client's interests and working closely with the project manager to manage day-to-day operations.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: What specific tasks does the project chair handle?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: The project chair has several responsibilities, such as evaluating project results, aligning project management objectives, clarifying the project framework, and acting as an escalation point in conflicts. They also manage project communication and marketing with the project manager. For instance, if a project’s goals need to be adjusted due to unforeseen risks, the project chair would lead that process.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: Does the project chair have a say in approving changes to the project?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Absolutely. The project chair can request and approve changes like updates to the project assignment, manual, objectives, organization, planning, final report, and financial releases—though major decisions might still require SteCo involvement.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: How often does the project chair meet, and who prepares those meetings?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: The project chair usually meets every two to three months or as needed. Similar to the SteCo, the project manager is responsible for preparing and attending these meetings.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: This is all starting to make sense. Can you summarize the main differences between the SteCo and the project chair?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Certainly! The SteCo focuses on strategic success, acting as the highest authority and decision-making body, while the project chair ensures operational success, managing day-to-day activities and representing the client’s interests. Together, they ensure the project runs smoothly at both strategic and operational levels.

subsections.title: 5.1 Phase 0: Initialization
subsections.content:
The NND project will be implemented in the following project phases:
Contents
• Formulation of the reason
• Clarification of the need to start the project
• Formulation of needs (description of the project objective)
• Proposal for project and solution strategy
• Preparation of the project application and compilation of documents
Results
• Approved project proposal
• Order to start the preliminary project

subsections.title: 5.2 Phase 1: Preliminary project
subsections.content:
Contents
• Kickoff meeting
• Current analysis
• Preparation of the project contract for the attention of the project chair, which includes, among other things, the
objectives and scope of the project are defined
• Analysis of project management components and creation of the required documents
• Structure of the project organization
• Rough schedule and milestone planning
• Describe tasks in work packages and link them to the schedule
• Financial and resource planning
• Obtaining the necessary financial resources
• Creation of an implementation concept taking into account all relevant
Business processes, especially change management, regulatory approvals, procurement and
documentation
Results
• Approved concept
• Rough cost and resource planning
• Loan application for the entire project

subsections.title: 5.3 Phase 2: Main project
subsections.content:
Contents
• Creation of quality requirements and execution specifications for the technical
documentation
• Preparation of commercial specifications with delivery and acceptance conditions and
Procedures for remedying defects and warranty cases
• D1 input
• Creation of project structure plan and elaboration of work packages
• Creation of a framework schedule including the essential dependencies
• Tendering of external services
• Resource analysis and release
• Risk analysis
• Creating a profitability analysis
Results
• Framework schedule including interfaces including the essential dependencies
• Detailed cost and resource plan, release of resources by line
• final negotiated offer for external services based on the technical and
commercial specifications

subsections.title: 5.4 Phase 3: Implementation
subsections.content:
Contents
• Creation of the basic technical concepts: Technical Design Guide & rough concepts
(network, infrastructure, application and client tier), as the basis for awarding the
data centers (RZ) and as a basis for the D2 approval documents
• Entering D2 and D3
• Planning, organization, monitoring and documentation of acceptance tests, trial operation
and commissioning, including preparation and review of the relevant schedules,
test procedures and acceptance documents
• Commissioning of the data center components (including management and monitoring systems)
• IT Security Audit
• Updating scheduling, financial and resource planning
• Claim Management
Results
• implemented and commissioned solution
• Training, instruction and provisional handover to the user takes place

subsections.title: 5.5 Phase 4: Conclusion
subsections.content:
Contents
• Completion of the final documentation
• D4 input
• Correction of any defects
• Processing of any official requirements
• Review of target achievement
• Claim Management
• Conducting project reviews and workshops on lessons learned, knowledge retention and project completion
• Preparation of the final project statement/credit statement
Results
• Final project report with lessons learned
• Relief of the project organization by the project chair and the steering committee

prerequisites: Basic understanding of project management principles
Knowledge of resource and financial planning
learningGoals: Understand the phases of project implementation
Learn to formulate project objectives and strategies
Gain insights into planning, execution, and evaluation of projects
Identify key deliverables and outcomes for each project phase

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Hello! Today, we’re going to explore the project phases of the NND project. By the end, you’ll understand how this process ensures successful project implementation.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: Great! What exactly are these phases, and why are they important?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Think of a project as building a house. You wouldn’t start without a blueprint, right? The NND project phases act like that blueprint, ensuring clarity, organization, and thorough planning at every step.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: That makes sense! So, what’s the first step in this process?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: The first phase involves formulating the reason for the project and clarifying why it’s necessary. It’s like asking, ‘Why do we need this house?’ Then, we define the project’s objective and propose a strategy to achieve it. This phase ends with an approved project proposal and an order to start the preliminary work.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: Okay, so the foundation is set. What happens next?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Next is the planning phase, which begins with a kickoff meeting. We analyze the current situation, define project objectives and scope, and prepare a project contract. It’s like setting up a detailed roadmap for your house construction, including tasks, schedules, and financial planning.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: How do financial and resource planning fit into this phase?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Good question! Imagine estimating the cost of materials and labor for building your house. Similarly, in this phase, we draft a rough budget and secure the necessary financial resources to proceed. The outcome includes an approved concept and a loan application for the project.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: That’s detailed! What happens after financials are sorted?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: We move to an in-depth planning phase. Here, we create quality requirements, define delivery and warranty conditions, draft a project structure plan, and perform risk and profitability analyses. Think of it as finalizing every detail before construction starts.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: And the results of this phase?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: The outcome is a detailed framework schedule, cost and resource plans, and finalized external service agreements. It’s like having a complete construction timeline and budget ready.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: Once that’s done, do we start implementation?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: Correct! The implementation phase kicks off with creating basic technical concepts, such as network and infrastructure designs, and involves commissioning components like data centers. It’s like assembling materials on-site for your house. We also conduct security audits, update schedules, and ensure everything aligns with the plan.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: What does the implementation phase deliver?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: It delivers a fully implemented and commissioned solution. Additionally, training and provisional handover are conducted to ensure users are familiar with the final product.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: How is the project wrapped up after implementation?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: The final phase focuses on project closure. It includes completing documentation, fixing any defects, reviewing target achievements, and conducting lessons-learned workshops. It’s like inspecting the house, ensuring everything is in order, and handing over the keys.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: And the results of this phase?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: The results include a final project report with lessons learned and the official closure of the project organization by the steering committee.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: This process seems thorough. How does it ensure project success?

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: By breaking down the project into these structured phases, we address each aspect systematically—from planning to execution and review. It minimizes risks, ensures quality, and aligns with business goals.

dialogue.speaker: Learner
dialogue.text: Got it! Thanks for explaining the NND project phases so clearly.

dialogue.speaker: Expert
dialogue.text: You’re welcome! To recap, the NND project phases include planning, execution, and closure—each with defined tasks and outcomes. This structured approach ensures successful project delivery. Great work today!
